facts.text: D.C. United has won four MLS Cups.
D.C. United has won four Supporters' Shields.
D.C. United has won three U.S. Open Cups.
D.C. United is the only United States team to win the Copa Interamericana.
D.C. United is tied with the LA Galaxy as the joint-most successful overall club in American soccer.
D.C. United was founded in 1994.
D.C. United played at Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium from 1996 until 2017.
D.C. United moved to Audi Field in 2018.
Bruce Arena was the head coach during D.C. United's successful period in the late 1990s.
Ben Olsen was fired as head coach of D.C. United in 2020.
Wayne Rooney was replaced as head coach by Troy Lesesne in January 2024.
Major League Soccer selected Washington, D.C. to host one of its first seven franchises on June 15, 1994.
D.C. United's original colors were announced as black and white, with red as the secondary color.
Bruce Arena led D.C. United to win two MLS Cup titles, a U.S. Open Cup title, a Supporters' Shield, a CONCACAF Champions' Cup, and a Copa Interamericana within the club's first two seasons.
D.C. United's inaugural match, which was also the first match in MLS history, was played on April 6, 1996, against the San Jose Clash.

D.C. United became the first club in MLS history to achieve the "league double" by winning both the regular season championship (Supporters' Shield) and league championship (MLS Cup) in the same year.
Eddie Pope scored the winning goal in the final when D.C. United defeated Toluca to win the CONCACAF Champions' Cup in 1998.
D.C. United is the first American club to win a CONCACAF club championship and the only American club to have won the Copa Interamericana.
As of 2022, only three American clubs have won the CONCACAF Champions' Cup or Champions League: D.C. United, LA Galaxy (in 2000), and Seattle Sounders (in 2022).
Bruce Arena left D.C. United to become the head coach of the United States men's national soccer team in October 1998.
D.C. United won their third MLS Cup title and their second Supporters' Shield title in the 1999 season under the coaching of Thomas Rongen.
In which season did D.C. United miss the MLS Cup Playoffs for the first time in franchise history?
2000 season.
Who did D.C. United lose to in the final of the CONCACAF Giants Cup held in March 2001?
Mexican club América.
What was D.C. United's position in the MLS regular season overall table during the 2002 season?
Last.
Who were D.C. United's joint top scorers in the 2002 MLS season, each scoring only five goals?
Ali Curtis and Bobby Convey.
In which year did D.C. United receive the first overall draft pick in the MLS SuperDraft, selecting Alecko Eskandarian?
Who replaced Ray Hudson as D.C. United's manager before the start of the 2004 season?
Polish manager, Piotr Nowak.
Freddy Adu became the youngest player in any professional sport in the United States since 1887 when he entered as a second-half substitute on April 3, 2004.
In 2004, D.C. United won their fourth, and as of 2022, their most recent MLS Cup title.
D.C. United became the first United States–based team to participate in Copa Sudamericana in 2005.
In 2006, the MLS All-Star Team, which included eight D.C. United players and was managed by D.C. United's manager Piotr Nowak, defeated English champions Chelsea.
D.C. United won their third consecutive Supporters' Shield title in 2006.
Tom Soehn replaced Piotr Nowak as head coach of D.C. United starting in 2007.
In 2007, D.C. United set a club record in points per game (1.8) and led the league in total goals (56).
D.C. United won the U.S. Open Cup in 2008.
Dave Kasper was promoted from Technical Director to General Manager of D.C. United in September 2007, a position he still held as of 2022.
Tom Soehn resigned as head coach of D.C. United at the end of the 2009 campaign, marking the end of the Soehn era with two major titles in three seasons.
Curt Onalfo was hired as the head coach of D.C. United after Caleb Porter rejected their offer.
Ben Olsen was named as the club's interim manager in August 2010.
D.C. United finished the 2010 MLS season with a record of 6–20–4, the worst in MLS that year.
Andy Najar won the MLS Rookie of the Year Award in 2010, becoming the first homegrown player to win the honor.
Ben Olsen assumed full-time managerial duties ahead of the 2011 season for D.C. United.
D.C. United won the U.S. Open Cup in 2013 under Ben Olsen's management.
Dwayne De Rosario won the MLS Most Valuable Player Award while playing for D.C. United in 2011.
Jason Levien and Erick Thohir became the new majority owners of D.C. United during the 2011–12 offseason.
In the 2012 MLS season, D.C. United finished in third place, their best finish since 2007.
D.C. United defeated New York Red Bulls in the Conference Semifinals of the 2012 MLS season but lost to Houston Dynamo in the Eastern Conference final.
D.C. United set a record for fewest wins in a season with only three victories in the 2013 MLS season.
D.C. United won the U.S. Open Cup in 2013 by defeating Real Salt Lake, marking the club's most recent major honor as of 2022.
D.C. United clinched first place in the Eastern Conference during the 2014 MLS season and went undefeated in CONCACAF Champions League group play, a first for an American club.
Ben Olsen won the MLS Coach of the Year Award in 2014 following D.C. United's turnaround season.
D.C. United opened their new soccer-specific stadium, Audi Field, in 2018.
Wayne Rooney, Luciano Acosta, and Paul Arriola were notable signings by D.C. United in the late 2010s.
Ben Olsen was relieved of his coaching duties at D.C. United in October 2020, after serving as the head coach for a club-record 10 seasons.
Ben Olsen became the third-longest tenured head coach for an MLS team in league history by October 2020.
Ben Olsen was hired as the Club President for the Washington Spirit in September 2021.
Hernán Losada was hired as the head coach of D.C. United for the 2021 season after previously coaching Belgian outfit, Beerschot.
Hernán Losada was fired as the head coach of D.C. United in April 2022 after about 14 months in charge.
Wayne Rooney was hired to coach D.C. United in July 2022.
Lucy Rushton was relieved of her duties as General Manager of D.C. United after the 2022 season.
D.C. United finished the 2023 season with 40 points, an improvement from 27 points the previous season.
Wayne Rooney was dismissed from D.C. United after failing to qualify for the 2023 MLS Cup Playoffs.
Ally Mackay was named D.C. United's new GM and Chief of soccer operations on November 20, 2023.
Troy Lesesne signed a three-year contract to serve as D.C. United's head coach on January 10, 2024.
Benteke won the 2024 MLS Golden Boot with a 23 goal haul for the season as D.C. United's captain.
D.C. United's original team colors, announced on October 17, 1995, are black and white, with red used to accent the home jersey.
The three stripes on D.C. United's uniforms represent the fact that the team's uniforms are made by Adidas, not the three jurisdictions of the Washington Metropolitan Area.
D.C. United's original shield, introduced in 1996, featured a black bald eagle facing right on a red field, clawing three soccer balls overlaid on three white stars.
The team's logo was redesigned before the 1998 season, reorienting the eagle to face left and removing the three stars below it.
D.C. United's victory in Major League Soccer's inaugural cup in 1996 is represented by a single gold-colored star and a soccer ball at the center of the eagle in their logo.
On December 10, 2015, D.C. United unveiled an updated logo designed by Peter Horridge, featuring a D.C. flag-inspired design across the eagle.
Guidehouse was announced as the jersey sponsor for D.C. United in a multi-year partnership on February 15, 2024.
D.C. United called the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium (RFK) home from the club's inaugural season in 1996 until the end of the 2017 season.
Audi Field, with a capacity of 20,000, hosted its first game on July 14, 2018, against Vancouver Whitecaps FC.
Audi signed a 12-year contract for the naming rights of Audi Field in February 2017.
The tentative deal for the construction of a new stadium for D.C. United was announced on July 25, 2013.
The stadium deal was signed into law on December 30, 2014.
Groundbreaking for the stadium began on February 27, 2017.
The ribbon cutting for the stadium occurred on July 9, 2018.
D.C. United played an MLS game against Columbus Crew SC at the Navy–Marine Corps Memorial Stadium on April 14, 2018, while Audi Field was under construction.
D.C. United has six major supporters groups: La Barra Brava, the Screaming Eagles, District Ultras, Rose Room Collective, 202 Unique, and La Banda del Distrito.
La Barra Brava was founded in 1995 by Latino fans, mostly Bolivian immigrants.
La Norte, a supporters' club affiliated with D.C. United, existed from 2001 to 2016.
D.C. United's mascot is named Talon, an anthropomorphic bald eagle.
D.C. United's primary rival is the New York Red Bulls, with whom they compete annually for the Atlantic Cup.
D.C. United also has a rivalry with the New England Revolution and a burgeoning rivalry with the Philadelphia Union.
D.C. United competes for the Coffee Pot Cup against the Charleston Battery of the United Soccer League.
George Soros was the primary financial backer and director of the group that owned the operating rights to D.C. United when the league was founded in 1995.
Anschutz Entertainment Group (AEG) became the sole investor-operator of D.C. United on January 8, 2002.
D.C. United entered into a strategic partnership with Brazilian club Atlético Mineiro in May 2007.
The operating rights to D.C. United were sold to D.C. United Holdings, which included Victor MacFarlane and William H.C. Chang, on January 8, 2007.
William Chang bought out his partners to control 100% of D.C. United in October 2009.
Indonesian businessman Erick Thohir and Jason Levien became partners in D.C. United in July 2012.
Jason Levien became the current majority owner of D.C. United after buying out Erick Thohir's stake in August 2018.
NFL running back Mark Ingram II joined D.C. United's ownership group as an investor on June 4, 2021.
Rapper Yo Gotti became a minority owner of D.C. United in 2021.
Rights to D.C. United matches not covered by MLS national television partners were held by NBC Sports Washington until the end of the 2022 season.
NBC Sports Washington held television rights for D.C. United from the team's inception in 1996 through 2015.
D.C. United concluded a new television deal with Sinclair Broadcast Group for the 2016 season due to frustrations with NBC Sports Washington's coverage.
D.C. United signed a $12 million contract for four years with FloSports for local rights in 2019, marking the first substantial rights fee for its local games.
D.C. United canceled their contract with FloSports before the final match of the 2019 regular season and opted to stream the remaining game on its website for free.
In 2023, D.C. United games were broadcast almost exclusively on Apple TV due to a rights deal making every MLS game available on the service.
D.C. United's first radio partner was WMET (1160 AM), which began coverage in 2003.
The D.C. United Academy includes notable graduates such as Bill Hamid, who has been called up by the U.S. national team, and Andy Najar, who has been capped for Honduras.
Four players from D.C. United during the 1990s were chosen as members of the MLS All-Time Best XI in 2005: Jeff Agoos, Eddie Pope, Marco Etcheverry, and Jaime Moreno.
In what year did D.C. United introduce the "Hall of Tradition"?
D.C. United hired Troy Lesesne to replace Wayne Rooney as coach on January 10, 2024.
D.C. United played in the first MLS match according to a Washington Post article published on December 6, 1995.
Eddie Pope scored the game-winning goal for D.C. United in the 1996 MLS Cup.
Jeff Agoos, a former D.C. United star, was elected to the Hall of Fame on January 16, 2009.
D.C. United won the U.S. Open Cup Final against Rochester with a score of 3-0 on October 30, 1996.
D.C. United defeated the Colorado Rapids 2-1 to win their second title, as reported on October 27, 1997.
D.C. United won the last Copa Interamericana, a fact highlighted in Howler Magazine on December 5, 2016.
D.C. United won the MLS Cup in 1996, 1997, 1999, and 2004.
The first match in MLS history was San Jose Clash defeating D.C. United 1–0 in 1996.
D.C. United's home stadium changed from RFK Stadium to Audi Field in 2018.
Wayne Rooney was appointed as the head coach of D.C. United in 2022.
D.C. United has rivalries with New York Red Bulls (Atlantic Cup), Charleston Battery (Coffee Pot Cup), New England Revolution, and Philadelphia Union.
Tampa Bay Mutiny was an MLS team from 1996 to 2001.
The MLS Cup winners in 2023 were Columbus Crew.
D.C. United's head coach position has been held by multiple individuals, including Bruce Arena (1996–98), Ben Olsen (2010–20), and Hernán Losada (2021–22).
Miami Fusion was an MLS team from 1998 to 2001.
Which team won the MLS Supporters' Shield in 2023?
Which team was the MLS Cup runner-up in 2024?
New York Red Bulls
In what year did the Philadelphia Union win the MLS Supporters' Shield for the first time?
Which team won the CONCACAF Champions League in 2022?
Seattle Sounders FC
Who were the CONCACAF Champions League winners in 2021?
Monterrey
What team won the MLS Supporters' Shield in 1996, the first year it was awarded?
Tampa Bay Mutiny
In what year did D.C. United win their first MLS Supporters' Shield?
Which team won the CONCACAF Champions League in 2018?
Guadalajara
Who won the MLS Cup in 2020?
Columbus Crew SC
In what year did Atlanta United FC win the MLS Cup?
Bethlehem Steel won the U.S. Open Cup three times consecutively from 1915 to 1917.
Fall River F.C. won the U.S. Open Cup four times, with their victories occurring in 1924, 1927, 1930, and 1931.
Maccabi Los Angeles won the U.S. Open Cup four times, with their victories in 1973, 1975, 1977, and 1978.
New York Greek American Atlas won the U.S. Open Cup three times consecutively from 1967 to 1969 and added a fourth title in 1974.
Seattle Sounders FC won the U.S. Open Cup four times within six years, with victories in 2009, 2010, 2011, and 2014.
Adidas was the kit manufacturer for a team from 1996 to 2001 with Mastercard as the shirt sponsor.
Volkswagen was the shirt sponsor from 2008 to 2013.
Leidos was the shirt sponsor from 2014 to 2021.
XDC Network was the shirt sponsor from 2022 to 2023.
Guidehouse is listed as the shirt sponsor from 2024 onwards.
Christian Benteke is the captain and a designated player (DP) for his team, wearing the number 20 jersey.
Bruce Arena won the 1996 U.S. Open Cup, 1996 MLS Cup, 1997 MLS Cup, 1997 Supporters' Shield, 1998 CONCACAF Champions' Cup, and the 1998 Copa Interamericana during his tenure from 1996 to 1998.
Thomas Rongen won the 1999 MLS Cup and the 1999 Supporters' Shield while coaching from 1999 to 2001.
Piotr Nowak led the team to win the 2004 MLS Cup and the 2006 Supporters' Shield during his time from 2004 to 2006.
Ben Olsen, coaching from 2010 to 2020, won the 2013 U.S. Open Cup.
The team has won the MLS Cup 4 times in the seasons 1996, 1997, 1999, and 2004.
The team has secured the Supporters' Shield 4 times in the seasons 1997, 1999, 2006, and 2007.
Jaime Moreno holds the team records for most games (329), most goals (131), most assists (102), most penalty kick goals (42), and most game-winning goals (26).
Raúl Díaz Arce and Christian Benteke are tied for the most hat tricks in the team's history, with 3 each.
Bill Hamid holds the team records for most shutouts (80) and most wins (103).
Christian Benteke was named the team's top goalscorer in both 2023 and 2024, scoring 14 and 25 goals respectively.
Jeff Agoos was inducted into the team's Hall of Tradition on October 16, 2008, for his contributions as a defender from 1996 to 2000.
Eddie Pope retired from professional soccer on July 18, 2010.
Richie Williams retired from professional soccer on October 15, 2011.
